Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They are expected to strictly follow all safety rules, such as using gloves, masks, and proper sanitizers for every task.
Story: I was just finishing up my shift as a housekeeping cleaner, carefully sanitizing the last doorknob and making sure my gloves were still intact. My phone buzzed—an acquaintance, Mark, was moving into a new apartment nearby and needed help carrying some boxes. He sounded desperate, and I knew he didn’t have many people to call. As an acquaintance, I felt I should help, to be supportive and friendly. But my mind raced with the protocols drilled into me at work: always wear gloves, never touch surfaces without sanitizing, and avoid close contact. Mark’s new place was still being unpacked, probably dusty and cluttered, and I doubted he had extra gloves or masks. If I helped, I’d risk breaking the safety rules I’d promised to uphold, possibly bringing germs home or back to work. Yet, if I refused, I’d feel like I was letting him down, not being the helpful person I wanted to be. I stood there, torn, the weight of both roles pressing on me, unsure which expectation I could afford to break.
